bibl.title: Letter fragment from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, September 8, 1900

div1.p: Kean discusses the responsibilities of his new position as part of the Cuban government. He mentions his son and a visit to the Governor's palace.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, September 8, 1900

opener.dateline:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
OFFICE OF SUPERINTENDENT
DEPARTMENT OF CHARITIES.
HAVANA. Sept. 8th

div1.p:
I was much pleas-
ed to get your note of the
1st yesterday on my return
from Matanzas where
I had been for a couple
of days on Beneficencia
business- Since I have
become a part of the Cuban
Government and have a
finger in great affairs
it seems that I dont
have time to write to
people & so people have
naturally stopped writing
to me- Now as to the clip-
ping which you enclosed
& which I return lest
you have forgotten it,
I think it is perfectly
reasonable & plausible-
No one would be surprised
if laborers who had been
exposed to it introduced
yellow fever into country
districts, so why not
malaria which is spread
in the same way & is
a far more chronic or
obstinate infection-

Mr. Bob in now flourish-
ing around the room
white-headed sturdy-
legged & jolly, I wish
that you could see him- He is just
the opposite of Martha in his develop-
ment being slow at talking & very
strong & precocious physically-

When he went to the porch steps yesterday
& his mother told him No! No! he turn-
ed around & gave her a big whack-
so you see he is getting to need a
licking- We are all so well, and so
comfortable in our new house, and
I am much interested in my new
work- Gen. Wood told me that if I took
this position I would have greater power
& greater responsibilities than the
Surgeon General - and I really believe
it is true- My authority in my dept-
is really despotic & the General rarely
alters an estimate or fails to grant
a request- Gen. Wood returned yesterday
looking thinner but brown & hearty-
The halls of the palace were crowded
with an anxious thing of Cuban poli-
ticians by 6 a. m. to greet him & the
only way he could have any private talk
